Comment: The other option is 6. Bh4 usaully leads to sharper lines. In this case I had no desire to play into complications. I prefer 6. Bxf6 because it removes a critical defender of d5 and put the dark bishop on a less active diagonal. The trade off is that I loss the long term advantage of the two bishops.

the most solid move that keeps the position closed and thus favoring knights. 7. e4 leads to open positions where black can enjoy his two bishops.

In the Queen gambit declined whites most pressing problem is where to develop the queen. Expereince bears witness to the fact that black easily equalizes after Qb3, Qc2 and Qe2.

my intention is to play g4-g5 and create lines to the king. By castling long my rooks are going to enjoy a lot of freedom on the kingside.
Black clears the strong d5 point for use
for black the most difficult problem in the openning is to develop the light bishop. Typically this is acheived through ...b6-Bb7 or a ...e5 break.

I have a slight lead in development so I want to take advantage of this plus by mounting a quick pawn storm before black has a chance to catch up. This strategy is designed to push and pressure my opponent to make a mistake. However, if black plays calm and strong defence this can prove inadequate
the correct response! black needs to pace with the game

In truth I do not like this move because my attack has stalled. In order to win I still have to solve the problem of my inactive knight. I had hoped for the manoveur Ne4-Nf6 but the strength of blacks bishop rules this out. Other possiblilies would be Ne2-Nf4, but that would open up ...Bd5 for black which is not good for me. Black for the moment is staying alive and is hoping for a white blunder. 

There is no really opportunity for white to press in with the attack so by playing 27. e4 as respite is ok because it frees me to play ne2-Nf4 without fear of ...Bd5. I however could not prevent all of blacks counter chances so...
